title: Why You Don’t Want to Find Meaning | Albert Camus' The Rebel
description:
Head to https://squarespace.com/unsolicitedadvice to save 10% off your first purchase of a website or domain using code UNSOLICITEDADVICE

Albert Camus' The Rebel is probably his most controversial book. If The Myth of Sisyphus wanted to discuss how to live individually in an absurd world, this goes one step further, and asks what an absurd society might look like. Specifically, Camus critiques the notion of absolute value, saying it is not just unfounded, but actually evil.

title: “Only Care About Yourself” | Egoism
description:
Head to https://squarespace.com/unsolicitedadvice to save 10% off your first purchase of a website or domain using code UNSOLICITEDADVICE

Important Correction (04/09/2025): I have read Stirner’s first section pretty straight here, but it is worth noting that some have interpreted it sarcastically, primarily regarding the racial element, but also the notion of progress and dialectic more generally. Here is a translators introduction where they make that very argument: https://theanarchistlibrary.org/library/max-stirner-the-unique-and-its-property. Here is another https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1016/j.histeuroideas.2007.11.001. I’ve also cut the bit about Stirner’s ‘racism’ since having done a bit more reading I’ve become convinced of the satirical interpretation of that. Additionally, if I were writing this again, I would probably not say that he is “often” thought to have influenced Nietzsche and the existentialists. While there is some evidence for this, I think I overstate things here, and it would be better to have said something like “there are some connections between these philosophies”. In hindsight, I am also quite unhappy with my presentation of Feuerbach. I would not say that he found these things “inherently” desirable, but rather that we just do desire them, out of our human essence.

There are few philosophers who are as controversial as Max Stirner, and his philosophy of egoism. He has managed to influence existentialism, anarchism, and more, and yet his ideas also tend to produce revulsion wherever they appear.

But does this philosophy hold up to scrutiny, and how should we approach it today? Well, let's find out.

title: How to Turn Suffering Into Art
description:

title: Does Society Need God?
description:

title: Philosophy Can Save Your Life | The Consolation of Philosophy
description:
Philosophy is often conceived as a way of making sense of a flawed existence. And perhaps no work is better for this than Boethius' The Consolation of Philosophy. He writes this book while awaiting his painful death and imprisonment for standing up for the Roman Senate in the face of corruption, and for that, he has been condemned. His insights can help any of us, whether we are dealing with something as significant as an unjust imprisonment, or simply making our way through the endless tiny sufferings of life itself. This is how philosophy can save your life.

description:

Most people in the debate around freewill online fall into two camps: Libertarians and Determinists. But a position that is often overlooked is Compatibilism - the idea that determinism is compatible with freewill. 

Today we will dip our toe into this debate, question whether determinism is compatible with freewill, and ask whether our entire conception of freedom is deeply limited.

title: Nietzsche's Guide to Destroying your Life | The Last Man
description:
NOTE: This is an old video and does not reflect my current views on Nietzsche. Among other things, I am unhappy with my treatment of Ressentiment and of Nietzsche’s opinion on Stoicism.

Friedrich Nietzsche has been called many things: a deep immoralist, an alarm bell for a nihilistic world, and a syphilitic madman. But today I want to talk about his philosophy of happiness, and why I think we can all learn a lot from his warnings about how a person can become truly miserable, wasting their potential in a lazy nihilism, and losing everything that makes them unique and peculiar in the process. We will begin with The Last Man and then explore through The Joyous Science, to see what insights it has in store for us all.

title: Nietzsche's Most Dangerous Idea | The Übermensch
description:
DISCLAIMER: This is an old video and my understanding of Nietzsche has moved on considerably since I put this out.

The Übermenschis one of Nietzsche's most famous ideas. They are meant to be the next evolution of mankind and a way to move beyond the values imposed on the world by religion. But it is also perhaps Nietzsche's most misunderstood idea. Often they are painted as simply a very powerful person or a sort of superhero, which gives an interpretation of the idea which is at best incomplete and at worst deeply misleading. So today let's get to grips with the Übermensch: Nietzsche's most famous and least understood idea.

title: The Freedom of Loneliness
description:

That is exactly where Henry David-Thoreau comes in. He spent 2 years in self-imposed isolation near Walden Pond in Massachusetts, and his book Walden is his account of what that was like.

title: He could only move his left eye | The Philosophy of Jean-Dominique Bauby
description:
Tragedy is inevitable. It is a key figure in the story of our lives and there is no way we can get away from it. But how do we deal with this tragedy? This is where I think the story of Jean-Dominique Bauby can really help us out. He suffered from Locked-In Syndrome, where he was mentally sound but almost entirely unable to communicate with the external world. He lived in what many would consider to be a personal hell, but he managed to write a spectacular book about the experience. The Diving Bell and the Butterfly chronicles his struggles, his coping mechanisms, and the lessons he has taken from his condition. And I encourage you all to read his work.

title: Stoicism’s biggest myth #philosophy #ancientphilosophy #stoicism
description:
Almost everyone gets this wrong about Stoicism. They think that Stoics suppressed their emotions.

In fact, the opposite is true. Stoics placed huge value on self-knowledge, including knowledge of your emotions. This is because they ultimately did not want to suppress their emotions, but treat them as information.

If you are angry, that tells you something! It tells you that there is something happening which is against your values.

If you are scared, it tells you that there is something you perceive as a threat.

All the Stoics said is that we should not be carried away by these emotions, but should take a step back, ask why we feel the way we do, and then decide a course of action.

It is quite similar to the methods taught in Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, and no one accuses them of suppressing their feelings.

title: How philosophers deal with loneliness
description:
Loneliness is a difficult part of the human condition. We all feel it from time to time and some of us feel it much more acutely than others. Luckily, as with most things, some philosophers are on hand to help us through this difficult psychological state. From Schopenhauer to Montaigne to Nietzsche to Pascal, there are a whole host of thinkers on hand to help us deal with loneliness like a philosopher.

We will begin with Arthur Schopenhauer, and undeniably quite lonely guy, before moving through Nietzschean thought, Stoicism, the Renaissance stylings of Michel de Montaigne, and finally ending on some wisdom from mathematician Blaise Pascal.

With loneliness as an increasing epidemic in our society, what better time to learn how to deal with it with a calm mind. To see its upsides, acknowledge its downsides, and greet it as a necessary but sometimes unpleasant part of life. In short, how can we all greet loneliness a little more philosophically? I hope by the end of this video, you will have a better answer to this question than at the beginning.

And if you liked it, stick around the channel for more on philosophy to improve your life.

title: The secret philosophy that will make you sad for life #philosophy #greekphilosophy
description:
Here is a surprising bit of wisdom courtesy of the most notorious group of Greek vagabond philosophers, the Epicureans.

Epicurus observed that when people gained more and more material goods, they did not seem to get any more happy. Once they could reliably feed themselves, had a roof over their head, and had a small collection of good friends, nothing they gained seemed to make them any happier.

Epicurus had accurately identified the phenomenon of hedonic adaptation, where beyond having their bare necessities covered, people very quickly adapt to new material fortune, and it loses its ability to make them happy.

If you don’t know this, you could spend your whole life chasing things that will never make you happy….good job you watched this then, really.

title: A disturbing psychology fact #philosophy #psychology
description:
Here is a dark fact about our moral psychology. We are much more likely to favour people we think of ourselves as being in “our group”. So if you are liberal you are more likely to like and support other liberals, and vice versa.

But if there is an in-group, there must be an out-group, and for every group of people you arbitrarily favour, there is a group of people you are unfairly discriminating against.

This in-group bias is thought to be a factor in many racist and sexist beliefs, but it does not just stop there. So where do you think you have fallen prey to this cognitive bias.

title: How propaganda tricks you #philosophy #logic
description:
You might believe a lot of nonsense just because it has been repeated to you a lot. Here’s why

The illusory truth effect is the human tendency to view an opinion as more likely to be true if they have heard it a number of times. So if I repeated to you the idea that exercise was actually very bad for your health over and over again, you would be more likely to believe it, even though it is total nonsense.

This trick is used by advertisers and propagandists to believe what they want you to uncritically.

Let me know where you have see this in the wild.

title: What they don’t tell you about Sherlock Holmes #logic #philosophy #sherlockholmes
description:
Did you know Sherlock Holmes never used deduction?

Despite what the detective will tell you, Sherlock is not a master of deductive reasoning but of abductive reasoning.

Deductive reasoning is where the conclusion of an argument cannot be false if all the premises are true. It is completely airtight. This sort of reasoning is best suited to maths, logic, and philosophy.

Sherlock instead uses abductive reasoning, where you evaluate a situation and try and come up with the best explanation for what has happened in that situation. This is much better suited for solving crimes, as very few of them occur in maths classrooms.

But let me know what you think.

#philosophy #logic #sherlockholmes

title: The most famous argument in Philosophy #philosophy #logic
description:
“I think, therefore I am” is the most famous argument in philosophy. But what does it actually mean?

Rene Descartes sat down one day and decided to doubt all his beliefs, in order to see what would hold firm in the face of such harsh scrutiny.

This then sparked a thought. If there was doubting and thinking going on, then there must be a doubter or thinker, and since he is the one doing the doubting, that must be him.

The statement is self-verifying. In order to think it, you have to exist.

Hence, I think therefore I am.

What do you think of this argument?

#philosophy #criticalthinking #logic #descartes

title: Top humanities study technique #study #student
description:
Here is a study hack that is fantastic for humanities subjects.

In the humanities, lots of essays are written about opinions on different issues. We might be arguing for a particular moral position, or political position, or analysis of a historical event.

Whatever your opinion is, I want you to challenge it from as many angles as you can.

Ask how you could be wrong about it. Ask why other people disagree with you about it and be charitable! What would a genius who disagreed with you say to thwart your position.

On the one hand, you might learn that you are wrong, and on the other you’ll have bolstered your opinion against any attack.

Either way, you’ll write better essays.

#study #cambridgeuniversity #philosophy

title: The most expensive logical fallacy #philosophy #logic
description:
Here is a fallacy that could cost you a lot of money. When an investor sticks with a poor investment because of all the money they have already put in, or someone stays in a bad relationship because of their “history” they are committing the sunk cost fallacy.

This is essentially where we persist with a course of action long before it has become pointless or even counter-productive, simply because we have already invested a lot of our time, energy, or money into it.

This is very tempting, because we think that if the action pays off, it will retroactively justify all the poor choices we have made up until that point.

But it won’t, so maybe back out of that pyramid scheme you are knee-deep in.

#study #cambridgeuniversity #student #logic #investment

title: The most common online logical fallacy #philosophy #logic
description:
If you’ve been in any online argument you have almost certainly encountered this fallacy. The straw man is where someone takes your argument, and mischaracterises it as a much more extreme and less reasonable position than you actually stated.

This is when someone gives an argument that we might want to fight climate change only for the other person to throw up their hands and say “so you want us to stop using all plastics? Just overnight?”. Of course, this is obviously not what they meant. But it is easy to have an argument where no one is actually addressing their opponent’s position, and instead spend all their time hacking at straw men.

So the next time you are arguing with someone, ask yourself if you are being charitable to their position, or are you strawmanning what they are saying. You can check whether you understand what they are saying by repeating your understanding of it back to them and asking whether that was what they meant.

#cambridgeuniversity #student #logic #philosophy #fallacy

title: A logical fallacy from politics #philosophy #logic
description:
This fallacy pops up in politics all the time. It is the “middle-ground fallacy” and it is when we assume the correct position in an argument is in the middle of all the opposing sides in an argument. This is such a natural human instinct because when we enter a discussion we often use the first things we hear as our anchor points - and if we get two opposing anchor points, then we tend to lay our flag firmly in the middle of them.

The reason this is a fallacy is because whether something is true bears no relation to what the middle ground between two arguments are. If one of the two positions has arguments that are sound and valid, and the other side has nothing to support their position, then it doesn’t matter what the middle ground between these two arguments are, the substantiated side is clearly right.

Remember that this just means that the middle ground between opposing positions is not always the correct position. It does not mean that it cannot be sometimes used as a rule of thumb.

#cambridgeuniversity #philosophy #logic #fallacy

title: A common logical fallacy #logic #philosophy
description:
A fallacy I hear all the time is the fallacy of composition. A good example of this is where someone says “some of this political group are evil, so the whole group is evil”. They infer directly from some individuals of a group that the whole group must share that property. The whole group could be evil, but it is not shown through this argument.

Here is a simple example of the same reasoning that is obviously incorrect. I can form a square with two triangles. The fallacy of composition would be to say “one of those triangles has three sides, so the square as a whole must have three sides”. This obviously does not follow: the square has four sides.

So watch out for this fallacy in the wild.

#logic #philosophy #cambridgeuniversity #fallacy

title: The best study technique you’ve never heard of #study #student #shorts
description:
If you are looking for a quicker way to reach a deeper understanding in your studies, then keep watching.

This technique was used by Richard Feynman to become one of the greatest physicists and educators of his time.

It comes in 4 steps:

Step 1: pick your topic

Step 2: write everything you know about that topic from memory, as if you were trying to explain it to someone who knew absolutely nothing about the topic. You don’t know true challenge until you’ve tried to explain Nietszche to a 5 year old.

Step 3: Check your notes or textbook to see where the gaps in your summary are.

Step 4: plug the gaps and refine your summary. Add new analogies, look at the topic from new angles, and explain it in new ways.

This technique forces you to grasp a topic at a deeper level by pretending to explain it to an uninformed 3rd party. Getting into “teaching mode” makes you look at the problem from so many different angles, inevitably giving you “eureka” moments.

#cambridgeuniversity #study #productivity #student

title: Is your studying boring? Watch this #study #studyhacks #productivity
description:
Most people find studying a completely miserable experience. All cooped up by themselves in a dark room hunched over a desk, but it does not have to be like this.

In fact, you can get more out of your studying by chatting it through with some friends. Gather some people round who are studying the same topic you are, and have a discussion about it.

You can harvest their perspectives, test one another, and teach one another the aspects of the topic you are most gifted at. And they can help you with what you are struggling with.

In fact, this is likely even more effective than studying by yourself, while being much more enjoyable. Provided you can keep the discussion focused.

So say goodbye to days trapped studying by yourself, because…

#study #cambridgeuniversity #productivity #student #studyhacks

title: A mind boggling paradox #logic #philosophy
description:
This riddle was used by Bertrand Russell to derail one of the greatest mathematical projects of the 20th century. It may also make your head hurt.

There is a town with one barber. The barber shaves only those men who do not shave themselves. In this town, who shaves the barber?

Just like that the logical trap is sprung. If the barber does not shave himself, then the barber must shave himself, but if he shaves himself, then he cannot shave himself.

In other words, if the barber shaves himself, then he doesn’t, but if he doesn’t, then he does.

Believe it or not, this whimsical tale about an imaginary barber made it impossible to ground mathematics in purely uncontroversial logical principles, and caused a debate that still rages to this day.

#cambridgeuniversity #study #productivity #philosophy #logic

title: How to learn anything quicker #study #student #learning
description:
Are you sick of studying something for hours, and still not feeling like you are learning anything. Well I am going to show you one of the most effective learning methods known to humankind.

It sounds grand, but it is actually very simple. It is to teach someone else whatever you are learning.

When we teach someone else, we are forced to prioritise information, look at things from different perspectives, and communicate our thoughts on a topic clearly and effectively. All of this cognitive effort tells our brain that this is really useful information that is worth remembering.
I can’t tell you the number of times I have suddenly grasped something at a much deeper level when I tried explaining it to someone else.

It is like magic for learning, and very time efficient. Just pull up a friend, or even explain to someone imaginary if you are a social recluse like me.

#study #cambridgeuniversity #productivity #student #teaching

title: Think like a Cambridge student using logic
description:
While at Cambridge I studied a lot of logic. And it has helped me immeasurably both while I was studying and in my wider life. With logic you can analyse an argument to see if it should be persuasive. You become much more alert to when someone is using rhetorical tricks to win you over, as opposed to cold hard reasoning. Overall, you become a better thinker and a better student.

So here I share with you the first steps to thinking like a logician. We learn how to put an argument in propositional form, and then how to check it for soundness or validity.

Stay tuned to become a better thinker, and a better student, with me.

#cambridgeuniversity #study #logic
